title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: Which area of mathematics deals with the likelihood of an event occurring?

options.label: A
options.text: Statistics

options.label: B
options.text: Probability

options.label: C
options.text: Data Analysis

options.label: D
options.text: Algebra

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 out of 512

options.label: B
options.text: 1 out of 750

options.label: C
options.text: 1 out of 1,024

options.label: D
options.text: 1 out of 2,048

multiple-choice.question: According to the fundamental counting principle, if there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then how many ways are there to pair the outcomes?

options.label: A
options.text: A + B

options.label: B
options.text: A - B

options.label: C
options.text: A times B

options.label: D
options.text: A divided by B

multiple-choice.question: If you randomly guess on a 10-question true/false quiz, what is the average number of questions you would get right?
If there are 20 questions on a standardized test and five possible answers for each question, what is the probability that you would get all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 in 1 million

options.label: B
options.text: 1 in 10 million

options.label: C
options.text: 1 in 50 million

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected average score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If you randomly guess on a 10-question true/false quiz, what can be determined about the probability of getting exactly 5 out of 10 questions correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the only possible outcome

options.label: B
options.text: It is the most likely outcome

options.label: C
options.text: It is not necessarily the most likely outcome, but it is the average score

options.label: D
options.text: It is impossible to get exactly 5 correct

multiple-choice.question: According to the fundamental counting principle, what is the correct formula to find the total number of possible outcomes for a 10-question true/false quiz with 2 possible answers for each question?

options.label: B
options.text: 2 times 10

options.label: C
options.text: 2 to the power of 5

options.label: D
options.text: 2 to the power of 10

multiple-choice.question: What element in storytelling has the power to connect people and provide a compelling reason to keep reading?

options.label: A
options.text: Statistical data and analysis

options.label: B
options.text: Official statements and reports

options.label: C
options.text: Authentic narrative

options.label: D
options.text: Factual summaries and updates

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are the three essential components of sourcing in journalism that form a trifecta?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, data analysis, and expert opinions

options.label: C
options.text: Overview sources, unofficial sources, and media reports

options.label: D
options.text: Official sources, academic research, and independent studies

multiple-choice.question: Which type of sources typically provide factual information, such as numbers and answers to questions like "how much," "how many," and "who"?

options.label: A
options.text: Overview sources, such as academics and consultants

options.label: B
options.text: Unofficial sources, such as individuals with personal experiences

options.label: C
options.text: Official sources, such as spokespeople and experts

options.label: D
options.text: Investigative journalists and researchers

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources have a broad understanding of a topic but are not directly involved or invested in it, providing a big-picture perspective?

options.label: A
options.text: Official representatives and stakeholders

options.label: B
options.text: Unofficial insiders and individuals with personal experiences

options.label: C
options.text: Overview sources, such as academics and consultants

options.label: D
options.text: Investigative journalists and researchers

multiple-choice.question: Which type of sources can offer unique, personal insights and help explain the underlying reasons behind an event or trend, providing the "why" behind a story?

options.label: A
options.text: Official spokespeople and experts

options.label: B
options.text: Overview analysts and academics

options.label: C
options.text: Unofficial sources, such as individuals with personal experiences

options.label: D
options.text: Academic experts and researchers

multiple-choice.question: In the context of journalism, what is the primary function of an anecdote in storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide statistical data and analysis

options.label: B
options.text: To add life and interest to a story, making it more relatable and humanistic

options.label: C
options.text: To give an overview of a topic or issue

options.label: D
options.text: To serve as an official statement or report

multiple-choice.question: What type of questions should journalists ask to elicit a compelling narrative from their sources and create a human connection?

options.label: A
options.text: Routine follow-up questions and clarifications

options.label: B
options.text: Official policy questions and factual inquiries

options.label: C
options.text: Surprising and thought-provoking questions that encourage storytelling

options.label: D
options.text: Leading or suggestive questions that influence the response

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main purpose of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey breaking news quickly and efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: To present detailed facts and updates in a timely manner

options.label: C
options.text: To create a human connection with the subject and encourage storytelling

options.label: D
options.text: To gather data for analysis and research purposes

multiple-choice.question: Which type of journalism allows for a more in-depth, nuanced approach to storytelling, often involving a slower pace of information delivery and a focus on narrative?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking news reporting and updates

options.label: B
options.text: Investigative journalism and analysis

options.label: C
options.text: Narrative journalism and storytelling

options.label: D
options.text: Opinion-based commentary and editorial writing

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the ultimate goal of narrative journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey information quickly and efficiently, focusing on facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: To present detailed facts and data analysis, providing expert opinions and insights

options.label: C
options.text: To create a connection between people through storytelling, making the personal universal and humanistic

options.label: D
options.text: To provide expert opinions and analysis, offering solutions and recommendations

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: According to Emily Dickinson, what is a book compared to?

options.label: A
options.text: A map that guides us through life

options.label: B
options.text: A frigate that takes us away to new lands

options.label: C
options.text: A tool for learning new skills and knowledge

options.label: D
options.text: A repository of memories and experiences

multiple-choice.question: What have researchers in psychology, neuroscience, child development, and biology discovered about stories?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a limited impact on a person's perspective and behavior

options.label: B
options.text: They shape culture and have the ability to change a person's point of view

options.label: C
options.text: They are solely for entertainment purposes and lack scientific basis

options.label: D
options.text: They can only influence children's development, not adults

multiple-choice.question: What is the central theme of Samuel Richardson's novel "Pamela"?

options.label: A
options.text: It reinforces the idea that social class determines a person's worth and status

options.label: B
options.text: It challenges the idea that social class determines a person's worth and promotes love-based marriage

options.label: C
options.text: It promotes the notion that women are inferior to men and lack agency

options.label: D
options.text: It challenges the concept of marriage altogether

multiple-choice.question: What characteristics does Darwin's theory of evolution emphasize?

options.label: A
options.text: Physical strength, aggression, and dominance

options.label: B
options.text: Intelligence, swiftness, and adaptability to change

options.label: C
options.text: Social status, wealth, and privilege

options.label: D
options.text: Emotional intelligence, cooperation, and altruism

multiple-choice.question: What do recent studies suggest about our perception of being a hero?

options.label: A
options.text: We are hardwired for competition and being solitary heroes in our own stories

options.label: B
options.text: We are members of a shared quest and interconnected with others

options.label: C
options.text: We are not heroes at all, but rather ordinary individuals

options.label: D
options.text: We are uncertain about what it means to be a hero in today's world

multiple-choice.question: What is one purpose of reading classic novels like "Pride and Prejudice" and "Great Expectations"?

options.label: A
options.text: To escape reality and indulge in fantasy

options.label: B
options.text: To learn about the past, gain new perspectives, and understand the evolution of societal values

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze literary techniques and critique authorial intent

options.label: D
options.text: To simply enjoy the stories without any deeper meaning or significance

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible interpretation of the Hunger Games series?

options.label: A
options.text: It promotes individualism, competition, and the survival of the fittest

options.label: B
options.text: It challenges individualism and competition, highlighting the importance of cooperation and social responsibility

options.label: C
options.text: It explores the consequences of rebellion against oppressive regimes and the effects of trauma

options.label: D
options.text: It has no real-world significance or relevance to contemporary issues

multiple-choice.question: What theme is explored in the novel "Uglies"?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of beauty, physical appearance, and conformity to societal standards

options.label: B
options.text: The dangers of pursuing a perfect body and letting the media define beauty and self-worth

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of individuality, self-expression, and nonconformity

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of technology on society and human relationships

multiple-choice.question: What theme is explored in the Seekers series?

options.label: A
options.text: It promotes the idea of global warming and its consequences, emphasizing the need for immediate action

options.label: B
options.text: It challenges the idea of global warming and its consequences, presenting alternative perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: It explores the relationship between humans and animals in the context of global warming and environmental degradation

options.label: D
options.text: It highlights the importance of conservation efforts and sustainability in the face of climate change

multiple-choice.question: What is the final question posed in the text?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the purpose of reading classic novels in today's world?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the significance of Darwin's theory of evolution in understanding human behavior?

options.label: C
options.text: What story will you try on next, and how will it shape your perspective and understanding of the world?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the main theme of the novel "Uglies", and how does it relate to contemporary issues?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of using logarithms in mathematics and science?

options.label: A
options.text: To simplify complex calculations involving extremely small or large numbers

options.label: B
options.text: To find the pH of water samples

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the concept of geometry

options.label: D
options.text: To convert between different number bases

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
What is the value of log base 2 of 64?
What is the formula for calculating the pH of a solution?

options.label: A
options.text: pH = log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: pH = negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: pH = log base 2 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: D
options.text: pH = negative log base 2 of the hydrogen ion concentration

multiple-choice.question: What happens to your eyes when exposed to a pH of 8.4, given that the pH of tears is approximately 7.4?

options.label: A
options.text: They feel itchy and red

options.label: B
options.text: They feel nice and comfortable

options.label: C
options.text: They don't feel anything

options.label: D
options.text: They get infected

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the base, exponent, and number in a logarithmic equation?

options.label: A
options.text: The base is the exponent raised to the power of the number

options.label: B
options.text: The base raised to the exponent equals the number

options.label: C
options.text: The base is the number raised to the power of the exponent

options.label: D
options.text: The exponent is the base raised to the power of the number

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the "log" button on a standard scientific calculator?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the square root of a number

options.label: B
options.text: To calculate the cube root of a number

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate logarithms of base 10

options.label: D
options.text: To calculate logarithms of any base

multiple-choice.question: What is the key difference between a logarithmic equation and an exponential equation?

options.label: A
options.text: A logarithmic equation solves for the exponent, while an exponential equation solves for the number

options.label: B
options.text: A logarithmic equation solves for the number, while an exponential equation solves for the exponent

options.label: C
options.text: A logarithmic equation has a base and a power, while an exponential equation has a number and a base

options.label: D
options.text: A logarithmic equation is used for small numbers, while an exponential equation is used for large numbers

multiple-choice.question: What are the pH values of water samples with hydrogen ion concentrations of 0.0000000398 and 0.00000000398, respectively?
What is the relationship between the pH of tears and the pH of water samples in terms of comfort for the eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: The pH of tears should be higher than the pH of water samples

options.label: B
options.text: The pH of tears should be lower than the pH of water samples

options.label: C
options.text: The pH of tears is irrelevant to the pH of water samples

options.label: D
options.text: The pH of tears should be close to the pH of water samples for comfort

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

options.text: Mechanical clock

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Hourglasses

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To synchronize timekeeping devices locally

options.label: D

options.text: Hourglass

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical clock

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: 14th century

options.label: C
options.text: 15th century

options.label: B

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.text: 30 time zones

options.label: C
